summary: These are call notes from October 16, 2024, summarizing a conversation with attorney Doug Wigdor. The discussion centers on a ChatGPT search regarding Leon Black's legal settlement involving Brad Edwards, and the potential hiring of a victim's attorney by a defendant, drawing parallels to the Bill O'Reilly case. The notes also mention an upcoming conference in Wigdor's case with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Doug Wigdor
persons.context: The attorney who participated in the call on October 16, 2024, discussing a ChatGPT search related to Leon Black's settlement and the involvement of Brad Edwards. He has an upcoming conference in his case with the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: A financier who retained Brad Edwards as part of a legal settlement regarding allegations filed against him, including a 2022 Jane Doe settlement, as discussed in the call notes.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: An attorney who was retained by Leon Black as part of a legal settlement of allegations against Black, including involvement in negotiating a settlement potentially related to a Jane Doe case.

persons.name: Bill O'Reilly
persons.context: Mentioned as a prior case where a victim's attorney was hired by the defendant, drawing a parallel to the situation discussed involving Leon Black and Brad Edwards.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of cases that were part of the ChatGPT search results discussed in the call notes.

keyFacts: A ChatGPT search was conducted regarding Leon Black's legal settlement, revealing that Black retained attorney Brad Edwards as part of settling allegations against him.
The settlement discussed includes a 2022 Jane Doe case, with Brad Edwards involved in the negotiation.
The call notes draw a parallel to the Bill O'Reilly case, where a victim's attorney was hired by the defendant.
ChatGPT initially provided information linking Edwards to Black but in follow-up stated there was no reliable source information, indicating a potential mistake.
Doug Wigdor has an upcoming conference in his case with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
